etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in First Part of Jeronimo. Origin uncertain; perhaps a euphemistic alteration of pest or pox

definitions: Used in various exclamatory or imprecatory expressions, as "pize on (also upon)"; "pize take", "pize light upon"; "out a pize", "what a pize". Compare "pox", "pest", "mischief".

etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Samuel Pegge (1733–1800), antiquary and writer. Origin uncertain; perhaps cognate with or borrowed from Middle Dutch pisen to play the game of ‘pisen’, of unknown origin

definitions: (A) To strike; specifically to hit (a ball) with the hand in the game of pize-ball. Also with down. (b) To throw or bowl (a ball) in pize-ball.
To throw a ball to (the batter) in pize-ball.
